ownedComment.body: A package of services and goods, accompanied by term and condition which is offered as a whole to (internal or external) customers.
An agreement established among the parties to use the payment card for payment. (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from ECB)

A formal or informal common understanding between two or more (legal competent) parties concerning one or more subject matters expressed in a set of arrangements, terms and conditions. (adapted from Legal System and FIBO)
An agreement established among the card holder and the card issuer to use the payment card for payment

A payment service to execute payment transactions through a payment card, including online payments. (Adapted from PSD)
A service that offers customers the use of payment cards.
An item created to serve a particular need, such as a credit card, a smart phone, an electronic signature, an electronic key, etc.
A specific Party who plays a specific role in the card payment transaction.
An arrangement which specifies to charge fees when banking transactions did take place, accompanied by the modalities to calculate and charge the fees and the related terms and conditions.

A device (payment instrument) that can be used by its holder to pay for goods and services or to withdraw money. (The dictionary of ECB)
Electronic money product that provides the cardholder with a portable and specialised computer device that typically contains a microprocessor. (ISO20022)
Payment Card means a category of payment instrument that enables the payer to initiate a debit or credit card transaction. (PSD)

A selection of interest product feature modalities for a specific interestment arrangement in a specific agreemen
The specification of the set of parameters used to calculate an interest amount. (adapted from ISO20022)
An arrangement into which both parties confirm on an interest product feature.
An even that triggers the fulfilment of a fee arrangement.
A fulfillment of a specific interest arrangement
Arrangement of paying back money previously borrowed from a lender.
The specification of the set of parameters used to calculate a repayment amount.
Instruction to execute a payment from a payer to a payee
The fulfilment of a repayment arrangement.
Transfer of money between two parties and/or accounts

An act, initiated by the payer or payee, of placing, transferring or withdrawing funds, irrespective of any underlying obligations between the payer and payee (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from PSD)
Instruction to pay an amount of money to an ultimate beneficiary, on behalf of an originator. (ISO20022)

A formal request to pay an amount of money owed for delivered goods or services.
What is invoiced should be conformant to - what is agreed in a customer agreement and - applicable regulations. - Good or services.

A payment transaction initiated by a payment card.
'Card-based payment transaction means a service based on a payment card scheme's infrastructure and business rules to make a payment transaction by means of any card, telecommunication, digital or IT device or software if this results in a debit or a credit card transaction. Card-based payment transactions exclude transactions based on other kinds of payment services. (PSD)

A measuring state on which movements in value or amounts of assets, rights and obligations are registered.
Comment: It is a bookkeeping instrument holding the amount or value of something by registering the movements in plus and min when events happen which have an impact on the position. The term "account" is usually associated to an accounting or bookkeeping concept to hold the financial or stock state of a business concept. An account will typically group the debit and credit entries for a specific aspect of the business resulting from transactions, Often accounts are represented as a T-account which is a visual aid used to depict an account. Above the top portion of the T would be the account title. On the left-side of the base of the T would be any debit amounts; on the right-side would be the credit amounts. A commonly used bookkeeping method is the double-entry method. This means that every transaction has at least 2 movements. If a customer pays 100 â‚¬ in cash, there is a decrease in the amount that the customer owes to the company (the customer position is decreased) an increase in the amount that the company has in cash (the cash position is increased)
An account can be assigning to one or more ledgers. A ledger is a group of accounts for a certain purpose. If there is need for multiple ledgers because of multiple purpose, an account can perfectly well assigned to multiple ledgers. When Ledgers are in real physical books, this is not possible. When ledgers are digital, accounts can be grouped into multiple groups at the same time. This practice is very rarely taught into courses for accounting, but in digital accounting, it is common practice.
Examples: stock account of a shop, cash register, bank account, financial accounting account, customer account, supplier account, ... Bank Account BE12 1234 5678 9012: is an individual banking account Accounts Payable, is a collective account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to its suppliers. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to suppliers. This account is managed usually in a General Ledger Supplier Account X, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to an individual supplier. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to an individual supplier. This account is managed usually in a sub-ledger. Stock Account x, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts in stock of a specific good. A payment service to take fund out of an account.
Arrangement on the provision and use of product instruments.
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.

A party represents an autonomous entity in which a bank has a business interest. It has a legal definition and identity. A party is a Person, Organization, (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from BIAN Party Working Group)
- Entity involved in an activity. (ISO20022)
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.

An act, initiated by the payer or payee, of placing, transferring or withdrawing funds, irrespective of any underlying obligations between the payer and payee (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from PSD)
A specific Party who plays a specific role in the card payment transaction.
The operation of e-commerce Gateway Service/System for a bounded period of time.

A payment transaction initiated by a payment card.
'Card-based payment transaction means a service based on a payment card scheme's infrastructure and business rules to make a payment transaction by means of any card, telecommunication, digital or IT device or software if this results in a debit or a credit card transaction. Card-based payment transactions exclude transactions based on other kinds of payment services. (PSD)

A device (payment instrument) that can be used by its holder to pay for goods and services or to withdraw money. (The dictionary of ECB)
Electronic money product that provides the cardholder with a portable and specialised computer device that typically contains a microprocessor. (ISO20022)
Payment Card means a category of payment instrument that enables the payer to initiate a debit or credit card transaction. (PSD)

The operation of a system -- typically an automated system -- for a bounded period of time.
Semi-permanent container of state for an information exchange with a system.
Time-bounded, temporal unit of context and continuity, identifying a unit of work.

A system for processing of e-commerce transactions for authentication, authorization and capture of the financial transactions.
An ecommerce payment gateway is a service that authorizes credit card payments and processes them securely with a users merchant account.

A payment service to execute payment transactions through a payment card, including online payments. (Adapted from PSD)
A service that offers customers the use of payment cards.
Set of integrated applications that provides centralised services such as clearing, netting, reconciliation, trading and/or settlement. (ISO20022)
An item created to serve a particular need, such as a credit card, a smart phone, an electronic signature, an electronic key, etc.

Authorisation of a card payment instruction or transaction.
Once the card and the cardholder have been successfully authenticated, authorisation is usually requested. However, this stage may be skipped in some cases (e.g. for transactions below a certain value), at the risk of the card acceptor. The terminal forwards the request for authorisation to the acquirer, to the acquirers processor or to the card scheme. If the acquirer and the issuer are one and the same, such transactions are referred to as on-us transactions and the acquiring bank carries out the authorisation itself. For transactions other than on-us transactions (i.e. where the issuer and the acquirer are not the same), authorisation may be obtained offline or online. In offline authorisations, the request is handled directly by the card acceptors terminal. In most cases, however, the authorisation is online and the request passes from the terminal to the acquirer. The acquirer may directly authorise or refuse the transaction, but will in most cases pass the transaction to a switching centre. The switching centre transfers the authorisation request and transaction information to the appropriate issuer or the authorisation platform (which may be the card scheme or a third-party service provider). The authorisation process usually includes checking the card details against a list of cards that have been reported as having been lost, stolen, used fraudulently or counterfeited. Checks on balances and card limits (i.e. daily and monthly limits) are usually also carried out. (Payment System ECB)

Authentication of card payment instruction or transaction.
Once the transaction has been initiated, the card and cardholder need to be authenticated. Authentication of the card usually involves reading the magnetic strip or chip, or checking the CVC/CVV2 (a three-digit code printed without relief on the back of the card, data which is not included in the magnetic strip) for card-not-present transactions. The cardholders identity is usually authenticated using a PIN code or a signature. (Payment System ECB)

An evaluation whether a party or system is what it claims to be.
A security mechanism for verifying: 1) the identity of an individual or other entity (including verification by means of a computer or computer application); and 2) the level of authority of that person or entity (i.e. the ability of that person or entity to perform specific tasks or activities). (ECB)
A set of transactions to be executed in one time.

A party represents an autonomous entity in which a bank has a business interest. It has a legal definition and identity. A party is a Person, Organization, (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from BIAN Party Working Group)
- Entity involved in an activity. (ISO20022)
The definition of an addressable space/position both in real and virtual environments with associated uses and entitlements
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.

An evaluation whether a party or system is allowed to do something.
The consent given by a participant (or a third party acting on behalf of that participant) in order to transfer funds or securities. (ECB)
A package of services and goods, accompanied by term and condition which is offered as a whole to (internal or external) customers.

An exposed function (an externalized functionality) that is able to deliver a certain value/benefit (a proposed definition adapted from Archimate).
A unit of functionality that a system exposes to its environment, while hiding internal operations, which provides a certain value (monetary or otherwise).
Comment:
A Service is something that is done by an actor for the benefit of an actor in the environment.
A system is the broad sense of the word. Means Business Service, Application Service, Technology Service, "huppeldepup" Service
Characteristics of a service:
A system (The Service Domain) Functionality is exposed (Action Term) It provides a certain value (monetary or otherwise)
Exposing functionality means that the internals of realizing the service is hidden for the beneficiary of the Service.
In BIAN a "Service Operation" is visualized as a "Business Service" , the "System" refers to the "Service Domain"
The name of a Service Operation is composed of an "Action Term" + "Subject Matter" which is the "Control Record" or the "Behaviour Qualifier".
Service is the intangible equivalent of a good. (ISO20022).
A type of economic activity that is intangible, is not stored and does not result in ownership; a service is consumed at the point of sale (FIBO & Business Dictionary)
A dispute related to the card payment.
A procedure for a dispute management and investigation related to a card payment.

A specific occurrence or matter requiring discussion, decision, or investigation, as by officials or law-enforcement authorities.
Is not synonym of Dispute. Dispute means: 1) A serious argument or disagreement 2) Disagreement followed by opposition against something. (Business Dictionary)

A step-by-step sequence of activities or course of action to perform a supporting office activity within the enterprise.
A procedure is a series of steps, taken together, to achieve a desired result.
Procedure as Generic Artifact: The performance of a supporting office activity within the enterprise (not product/service fulfillment specific)
An (structured) interaction between a customer and a financial institution.

A course of action must be followed to execute the procedure.
Worksteps as Behaviour Qualifier Type: The main worksteps to be followed in the execution of the procedure
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific Customer Relationship.

A payment transaction initiated by a payment card.
'Card-based payment transaction means a service based on a payment card scheme's infrastructure and business rules to make a payment transaction by means of any card, telecommunication, digital or IT device or software if this results in a debit or a credit card transaction. Card-based payment transactions exclude transactions based on other kinds of payment services. (PSD)

A specific relationship between a specific Bank (= party acting as a supplier of banking services) and one or more other involved parties acting as (potential) consumers of banking services as agreed in one or more banking product or service offerings and/or agreements.
Dispute resolution for a card case.

Synonym= Dispute Resolution
A process for resolving differences between two or more parties or groups. In business practice the resolution seeks to achieve fairness for all participants, and is often moderated by a third party. There is often a dispute resolution clause in contracts that defines how a disagreement is to be resolved. (Business Dictionary)
dispute resolution. BusinessDictionary.com. Retrieved August 22, 2019, from BusinessDictionary.com website: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/dispute-resolution.html
A device allowing the use of payment cards at a physical (not virtual) point of sale. The payment information is captured either manually on paper vouchers or by electronic means.
Set of integrated applications that provides centralised services such as clearing, netting, reconciliation, trading and/or settlement. (ISO20022)

The operation of a system -- typically an automated system -- for a bounded period of time.
Semi-permanent container of state for an information exchange with a system.
Time-bounded, temporal unit of context and continuity, identifying a unit of work.
An item created to serve a particular need, such as a credit card, a smart phone, an electronic signature, an electronic key, etc.

A payment transaction initiated by a payment card.
'Card-based payment transaction means a service based on a payment card scheme's infrastructure and business rules to make a payment transaction by means of any card, telecommunication, digital or IT device or software if this results in a debit or a credit card transaction. Card-based payment transactions exclude transactions based on other kinds of payment services. (PSD)
A network for handling Card POS.
A settlement process for card-based transaction (transactions between the Issuers and the Acquirers through the Card Networks).

A step-by-step sequence of activities or course of action to perform a supporting office activity within the enterprise.
A procedure is a series of steps, taken together, to achieve a desired result.
Procedure as Generic Artifact: The performance of a supporting office activity within the enterprise (not product/service fulfillment specific)
A procedure for managing the card settlement process.

A payment transaction initiated by a payment card.
'Card-based payment transaction means a service based on a payment card scheme's infrastructure and business rules to make a payment transaction by means of any card, telecommunication, digital or IT device or software if this results in a debit or a credit card transaction. Card-based payment transactions exclude transactions based on other kinds of payment services. (PSD)
A specific party who plays a specific role in the card settlement.

Process which consists in transferring the proceeds related to a trade from one party to the next one. (ISO20022)
The completion of a transaction or of processing with the aim of discharging participants obligations through the transfer of funds and/or securities. A settlement may be final or provisional. (ECB)

A party represents an autonomous entity in which a bank has a business interest. It has a legal definition and identity. A party is a Person, Organization, (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from BIAN Party Working Group)
- Entity involved in an activity. (ISO20022)
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.

The operation of a system -- typically an automated system -- for a bounded period of time.
Semi-permanent container of state for an information exchange with a system.
Time-bounded, temporal unit of context and continuity, identifying a unit of work.
A specific Party who plays a specific role in the card payment transaction.

A transaction processing software (system) which receives transaction request from more than one interface ( ATM, POS , mPOS, payment gateway and etc) and obtain authroisation for transaction from debit cards or credit card hosts or prepaid card host.

A payment transaction initiated by a payment card.
'Card-based payment transaction means a service based on a payment card scheme's infrastructure and business rules to make a payment transaction by means of any card, telecommunication, digital or IT device or software if this results in a debit or a credit card transaction. Card-based payment transactions exclude transactions based on other kinds of payment services. (PSD)
The operation of CardTransactionSwitch System for a bounded period of time.
Set of integrated applications that provides centralised services such as clearing, netting, reconciliation, trading and/or settlement. (ISO20022)

A kind of action.
Functions as Behaviour Qualifier: The collection of operational services/functions offered by the operational facility.
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.

A party represents an autonomous entity in which a bank has a business interest. It has a legal definition and identity. A party is a Person, Organization, (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from BIAN Party Working Group)
- Entity involved in an activity. (ISO20022)

A course of action must be followed to execute the procedure.
Worksteps as Behaviour Qualifier Type: The main worksteps to be followed in the execution of the procedure
Specifies the system which plays a role in the clearing process. (ISO20022)

Mechanism allowing financial institutions that are members of a clearing house to pay and to receive the amounts linked to the transactions that they have executed on the market. The addition of all the positions per product results in one net position (due or to receive) with the clearing house or the central clearing counterparty. (ISO20022)
The process of transmitting, reconciling and, in some cases, confirming transactions prior to settlement, potentially including the netting of transactions and the establishment of final positions for settlement. Sometimes this term is also used (imprecisely) to cover settlement. For the clearing of futures and options, this term also refers to the daily balancing of profits and losses and the daily calculation of collateral requirements ( Bank for International Settlements Glossary)
A clearing process for card based transactions.
A procedure for managing the card clearing process.

A step-by-step sequence of activities or course of action to perform a supporting office activity within the enterprise.
A procedure is a series of steps, taken together, to achieve a desired result.
Procedure as Generic Artifact: The performance of a supporting office activity within the enterprise (not product/service fulfillment specific)
A set of transactions to be executed in one time.

A payment transaction initiated by a payment card.
'Card-based payment transaction means a service based on a payment card scheme's infrastructure and business rules to make a payment transaction by means of any card, telecommunication, digital or IT device or software if this results in a debit or a credit card transaction. Card-based payment transactions exclude transactions based on other kinds of payment services. (PSD)
A procedure for managing the clearing process.
An arrangement (obligation and right) defined for doing the clearing and settlement of a card based transaction or a batch of card based transactions.
A specific Party who plays a specific role in the card payment transaction.
The fulfillment of a card clrearing and settlement obligation.
Term and condition defined for clearing and settlement of a card based transaction or a batch of card based transactions.

Authorisation of a card payment instruction or transaction.
Once the card and the cardholder have been successfully authenticated, authorisation is usually requested. However, this stage may be skipped in some cases (e.g. for transactions below a certain value), at the risk of the card acceptor. The terminal forwards the request for authorisation to the acquirer, to the acquirers processor or to the card scheme. If the acquirer and the issuer are one and the same, such transactions are referred to as on-us transactions and the acquiring bank carries out the authorisation itself. For transactions other than on-us transactions (i.e. where the issuer and the acquirer are not the same), authorisation may be obtained offline or online. In offline authorisations, the request is handled directly by the card acceptors terminal. In most cases, however, the authorisation is online and the request passes from the terminal to the acquirer. The acquirer may directly authorise or refuse the transaction, but will in most cases pass the transaction to a switching centre. The switching centre transfers the authorisation request and transaction information to the appropriate issuer or the authorisation platform (which may be the card scheme or a third-party service provider). The authorisation process usually includes checking the card details against a list of cards that have been reported as having been lost, stolen, used fraudulently or counterfeited. Checks on balances and card limits (i.e. daily and monthly limits) are usually also carried out. (Payment System ECB)
An arrangement which specifies to charge fees when banking transactions did take place, accompanied by the modalities to calculate and charge the fees and the related terms and conditions.

An act, initiated by the payer or payee, of placing, transferring or withdrawing funds, irrespective of any underlying obligations between the payer and payee (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from PSD)

Network for handling the card based transaction (e.g. Visa, MC, AMEX, Diners, etc.)
A card network are networks of issuing and acquiring banks through which payment cards of some certain brand are processed. two types of card networks can be pointed out, namely, credit card associations (Visa, MasterCard, Discover, Amex, etc.) and PINless debit card networks (NYCE, PULSE, Maestro, Interlink, Cirrus, etc.).
Card networks are financial services companies that enables, processes and settles payments between card issuing banks and merchant banks worldwide. Examples are Visa, MasterCard, Discover, RuPay etc.
A card network is a system of connecting merchants and card issuers. A middle person that collects funds from card issuer and pays it to the merchant. Visa and MasterCard are examples of card networks.

A measuring state on which movements in value or amounts of assets, rights and obligations are registered.
Comment: It is a bookkeeping instrument holding the amount or value of something by registering the movements in plus and min when events happen which have an impact on the position. The term "account" is usually associated to an accounting or bookkeeping concept to hold the financial or stock state of a business concept. An account will typically group the debit and credit entries for a specific aspect of the business resulting from transactions, Often accounts are represented as a T-account which is a visual aid used to depict an account. Above the top portion of the T would be the account title. On the left-side of the base of the T would be any debit amounts; on the right-side would be the credit amounts. A commonly used bookkeeping method is the double-entry method. This means that every transaction has at least 2 movements. If a customer pays 100 â‚¬ in cash, there is a decrease in the amount that the customer owes to the company (the customer position is decreased) an increase in the amount that the company has in cash (the cash position is increased)

If there is need for multiple ledgers because of multiple purpose, an account can perfectly well assigned to multiple ledgers. When Ledgers are in real physical books, this is not possible. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to suppliers. A bank account upon which the financial position of card payment arrangements are managed.

A party represents an autonomous entity in which a bank has a business interest. It has a legal definition and identity. A party is a Person, Organization, (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from BIAN Party Working Group)
- Entity involved in an activity. (ISO20022)
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.
An item created to serve a particular need, such as a credit card, a smart phone, an electronic signature, an electronic key, etc.
the rating/certification derived as result of an applied test assessment of an entity using specific testing criteria

A measure taken to check the quality, performance, or reliability of (something), especially before putting it into widespread use or practice
Tests are a collection of one or more tests evaluations that can be made to certify a subject. (Behavior Qualifier Type)

Authorisation of a card payment instruction or transaction.
Once the card and the cardholder have been successfully authenticated, authorisation is usually requested. However, this stage may be skipped in some cases (e.g. for transactions below a certain value), at the risk of the card acceptor. The terminal forwards the request for authorisation to the acquirer, to the acquirers processor or to the card scheme. If the acquirer and the issuer are one and the same, such transactions are referred to as on-us transactions and the acquiring bank carries out the authorisation itself. For transactions other than on-us transactions (i.e. where the issuer and the acquirer are not the same), authorisation may be obtained offline or online. In offline authorisations, the request is handled directly by the card acceptors terminal. In most cases, however, the authorisation is online and the request passes from the terminal to the acquirer. The acquirer may directly authorise or refuse the transaction, but will in most cases pass the transaction to a switching centre. The switching centre transfers the authorisation request and transaction information to the appropriate issuer or the authorisation platform (which may be the card scheme or a third-party service provider). The authorisation process usually includes checking the card details against a list of cards that have been reported as having been lost, stolen, used fraudulently or counterfeited. Checks on balances and card limits (i.e. daily and monthly limits) are usually also carried out. (Payment System ECB)
A package of services and goods, accompanied by term and condition which is offered as a whole to (internal or external) customers.

A payment transaction initiated by a payment card.
'Card-based payment transaction means a service based on a payment card scheme's infrastructure and business rules to make a payment transaction by means of any card, telecommunication, digital or IT device or software if this results in a debit or a credit card transaction. Card-based payment transactions exclude transactions based on other kinds of payment services. (PSD)

A device (payment instrument) that can be used by its holder to pay for goods and services or to withdraw money. (The dictionary of ECB)
Electronic money product that provides the cardholder with a portable and specialised computer device that typically contains a microprocessor. (ISO20022)
Payment Card means a category of payment instrument that enables the payer to initiate a debit or credit card transaction. (PSD)

An act, initiated by the payer or payee, of placing, transferring or withdrawing funds, irrespective of any underlying obligations between the payer and payee (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from PSD)

An evaluation whether a party or system is allowed to do something.
The consent given by a participant (or a third party acting on behalf of that participant) in order to transfer funds or securities. (ECB)
A specific Party who plays a specific role in the card payment transaction.

Authentication of card payment instruction or transaction.
Once the transaction has been initiated, the card and cardholder need to be authenticated. Authentication of the card usually involves reading the magnetic strip or chip, or checking the CVC/CVV2 (a three-digit code printed without relief on the back of the card, data which is not included in the magnetic strip) for card-not-present transactions. The cardholders identity is usually authenticated using a PIN code or a signature. (Payment System ECB)

An evaluation whether a party or system is what it claims to be.
A security mechanism for verifying: 1) the identity of an individual or other entity (including verification by means of a computer or computer application); and 2) the level of authority of that person or entity (i.e. the ability of that person or entity to perform specific tasks or activities). (ECB)
A bank account upon which the financial position of card payment arrangements are managed.
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
A request to do something.
An instruction to do something expressed in an amount of money.

A planned or performed action in the context of concluding or fulfilling an agreement.
Act to do something.

A party represents an autonomous entity in which a bank has a business interest. It has a legal definition and identity. A party is a Person, Organization, (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from BIAN Party Working Group)
- Entity involved in an activity. (ISO20022)
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.
Instruction to pay an amount of money to an ultimate beneficiary, on behalf of an originator. (ISO20022)
A request to do something.
Party who plays a specific role in a specific payment instruction.

An act, initiated by the payer or payee, of placing, transferring or withdrawing funds, irrespective of any underlying obligations between the payer and payee (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from PSD)
Instruction to execute a payment from a payer to a payee
Transfer of money between two parties and/or accounts
An instruction to do something expressed in an amount of money.
An arrangement which specifies the promise to offer the payment service, accompanied by the payment modalities.
Account where the funds are to be credited/debited for a payment instruction.

A payment service to execute payment transactions through a payment card, including online payments. (Adapted from PSD)
A service that offers customers the use of payment cards.
Type of payment card as a product.
Configuration specified for the payment card product.

A contract that gives rise to a financial asset of one entity and a financial liability or equity instrument of another entity. (IFRS) https://www.iasplus.com/en/standards/ias/ias32#:~:text=Key%20definitions%20%5BIAS%2032.11%5D,equity%20instrument%20of%20another%20entity
Financial instruments are financial contracts of different nature made between institutional units. These comprise the full range of financial claims and liabilities between institutional units, including contingent liabilities like guarantees, commitments, etc. (ISO 10962)
An arrangement which specifies the promise to offer the payment service, accompanied by the payment modalities.
A package of services and goods, accompanied by term and condition which is offered as a whole to (internal or external) customers.
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
An arrangement defining the applicable features for a loan account agreement.
ServiceArrangement defined for cash financial instruments like FeeArrangement, DepositArrangement, ...
An arrangement defining the applicable features for a Corporate Deposit Agreement.

An arrangement defining the applicable features for a savings account agreement.
The arrangement type is one of those possible/mandatory for the sale of a savings account product. The actual arrangements are a selection of those offered under the savings account product.
Arrangement whitin the product sales agreement
The fulfilment of the engagements (obligations/rights) taken in an arrangement
An instruction to do something expressed in an amount of money.
A request to do something.
A transaction that changes the financial position (the status of the finances) of involved party.

A planned or performed action in the context of concluding or fulfilling an agreement.
Act to do something.
Transfer of money between two parties and/or accounts
Instruction to execute a payment from a payer to a payee
A record of events/entries.

The operation of a system -- typically an automated system -- for a bounded period of time.
Semi-permanent container of state for an information exchange with a system.
Time-bounded, temporal unit of context and continuity, identifying a unit of work.

An exposed function (an externalized functionality) that is able to deliver a certain value/benefit (a proposed definition adapted from Archimate).
A unit of functionality that a system exposes to its environment, while hiding internal operations, which provides a certain value (monetary or otherwise).
Comment:
A Service is something that is done by an actor for the benefit of an actor in the environment.
A system is the broad sense of the word. Means Business Service, Application Service, Technology Service, "huppeldepup" Service
Characteristics of a service:
A system (The Service Domain) Functionality is exposed (Action Term) It provides a certain value (monetary or otherwise)
Exposing functionality means that the internals of realizing the service is hidden for the beneficiary of the Service.
In BIAN a "Service Operation" is visualized as a "Business Service" , the "System" refers to the "Service Domain"
The name of a Service Operation is composed of an "Action Term" + "Subject Matter" which is the "Control Record" or the "Behaviour Qualifier".
Service is the intangible equivalent of a good. (ISO20022).
A type of economic activity that is intangible, is not stored and does not result in ownership; a service is consumed at the point of sale (FIBO & Business Dictionary)
An subject matter about which arrangements should or can be made when selling a savings account product.

An evaluation whether a party or system is allowed to do something.
The consent given by a participant (or a third party acting on behalf of that participant) in order to transfer funds or securities. (ECB)

An evaluation whether a party or system is what it claims to be.
A security mechanism for verifying: 1) the identity of an individual or other entity (including verification by means of a computer or computer application); and 2) the level of authority of that person or entity (i.e. the ability of that person or entity to perform specific tasks or activities). (ECB)
the rating/certification derived as result of an applied test assessment of an entity using specific testing criteria
a distinctive attribute or aspect of something.

A specific occurrence or matter requiring discussion, decision, or investigation, as by officials or law-enforcement authorities.
Is not synonym of Dispute. Dispute means: 1) A serious argument or disagreement 2) Disagreement followed by opposition against something. (Business Dictionary)

A step-by-step sequence of activities or course of action to perform a supporting office activity within the enterprise.
A procedure is a series of steps, taken together, to achieve a desired result.
Procedure as Generic Artifact: The performance of a supporting office activity within the enterprise (not product/service fulfillment specific)
Event related to a specific Customer or Customer Relationship.

A specific Relationship (= an instance of a Relationship Class) between a specific party acting as the Bank and one or more other specific involved Parties. A Relationship is a logical unit of collaboration between two or more involved Parties.

A relationship between two or more parties; the parties involved are specified in terms of the roles they play in the relationship.
A Party Relationship is a connection between an instance of a Party and two or more instances of associated objects in the relationship.

Synonym= Dispute Resolution
A process for resolving differences between two or more parties or groups. In business practice the resolution seeks to achieve fairness for all participants, and is often moderated by a third party. There is often a dispute resolution clause in contracts that defines how a disagreement is to be resolved. (Business Dictionary)
dispute resolution. BusinessDictionary.com. Retrieved August 22, 2019, from BusinessDictionary.com website: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/dispute-resolution.html

Process which consists in transferring the proceeds related to a trade from one party to the next one. (ISO20022)
The completion of a transaction or of processing with the aim of discharging participants obligations through the transfer of funds and/or securities. A settlement may be final or provisional. (ECB)

Mechanism allowing financial institutions that are members of a clearing house to pay and to receive the amounts linked to the transactions that they have executed on the market. The addition of all the positions per product results in one net position (due or to receive) with the clearing house or the central clearing counterparty. (ISO20022)
The process of transmitting, reconciling and, in some cases, confirming transactions prior to settlement, potentially including the netting of transactions and the establishment of final positions for settlement. Sometimes this term is also used (imprecisely) to cover settlement. For the clearing of futures and options, this term also refers to the daily balancing of profits and losses and the daily calculation of collateral requirements ( Bank for International Settlements Glossary)
A procedure for managing the clearing process.
An Arrangements (right and obligation) defined for doing the clearing and settlement of a transaction or a batch of transactions.

An event related to the behaviour performed by an actor.
Comment: An actor can be a party or a machine An action Includes various types of requests, orders and financial transactions. Includes responses where appropriate. An action is an event which means that the concept describes the result of acting.

A Classification Hierarchy that distinguishes between Party Roles according to the associated object type.
Associated object types are for example location (PartyLocation), agreement (Agreement Involvement) , Product (Product Involvement); etc.

An arrangement into which is promised to deliver a specific service.
Comment: Most service arrangements are instantiations of Product Services

A payment transaction initiated by a payment card.
'Card-based payment transaction means a service based on a payment card scheme's infrastructure and business rules to make a payment transaction by means of any card, telecommunication, digital or IT device or software if this results in a debit or a credit card transaction. Card-based payment transactions exclude transactions based on other kinds of payment services. (PSD)
Amount added to the total price of the transaction and received in cash by the customer. (ISO20022)
Place where the merchant actually performed the transaction. (ISO20022)
Specifies the direction of a payment. (ISO20022)
Identifies the type of the communication channels used by the cardholder to the acceptor system. (ISO20022)
Describes the Point of Interaction through which the payment by card was initiated. (ISO20022)
Local date and time of the transaction assigned by the POI (Point Of Interaction). (ISO20022)
Indicates the environment of the transaction like Merchant, Private, Public, Branch.
Country of the merchant where the transaction took place. (ISO20022)
Network used for handling the card payment transaction.
An agreement established among the parties to use the payment card for payment. (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from ECB)
Amount of the payment card.
Currency of the payment card.
Limit specified on a payment card.
Tax specified on a payment card.
A specific Party who plays a specific role in the card payment transaction.
An agreement established among the card holder and the card issuer to use the payment card for payment
Identifier of arrangement/obligation in the payment card agreement.
An item created to serve a particular need, such as a credit card, a smart phone, an electronic signature, an electronic key, etc.

Reference to the device type of the device
A device has the characteristics of the device type it belongs to possibly specified e.g. a device of the type "cheque book" will have cheques. The device specifies how many and what the number range is. e.g. an electronic banking app consists of software modules, the device specifies what version

Property of a device relevant for its use.
A device has the characteristics of the device type it belongs to,possibly specified e.g. . a device of the type "cheque book" will have cheques. The device specifies how many and what the number range is. e.g. an electronic banking app consists of software modules, the device specifies what version

An element of the device that can be used independently and is individually identified
e.g. a cheque in a chequebook

The life cycle stage of a device
e.g. active, defect

A device (payment instrument) that can be used by its holder to pay for goods and services or to withdraw money. (The dictionary of ECB)
Electronic money product that provides the cardholder with a portable and specialised computer device that typically contains a microprocessor. (ISO20022)
Payment Card means a category of payment instrument that enables the payer to initiate a debit or credit card transaction. (PSD)
Type of card, e.g., credit card. (ISO20022)
Number embossed on a card that links the card to the account owner and account servicer (sometimes called personal account number or PAN). (ISO20022)
Year and month the card is available for use. (ISO20022)
Year and month the card expires. (ISO20022)
Security code written on the card, sometimes called card security code (CSC). (ISO20022)
The bank identification number uniquely identifies the institution issuing the card. The BIN is key in the process of matching transactions to the issuer of the charge card.

An act, initiated by the payer or payee, of placing, transferring or withdrawing funds, irrespective of any underlying obligations between the payer and payee (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from PSD)
An identifier that allows to uniquely refer to a Payment Transaction.
The payment mechanism the bank decides to use in the transaction to execute a payment instruction

A system for processing of e-commerce transactions for authentication, authorization and capture of the financial transactions.
An ecommerce payment gateway is a service that authorizes credit card payments and processes them securely with a users merchant account.

A measuring state on which movements in value or amounts of assets, rights and obligations are registered.
Comment: It is a bookkeeping instrument holding the amount or value of something by registering the movements in plus and min when events happen which have an impact on the position. The term "account" is usually associated to an accounting or bookkeeping concept to hold the financial or stock state of a business concept. An account will typically group the debit and credit entries for a specific aspect of the business resulting from transactions, Often accounts are represented as a T-account which is a visual aid used to depict an account. Above the top portion of the T would be the account title. On the left-side of the base of the T would be any debit amounts; on the right-side would be the credit amounts. A commonly used bookkeeping method is the double-entry method. This means that every transaction has at least 2 movements. If a customer pays 100 â‚¬ in cash, there is a decrease in the amount that the customer owes to the company (the customer position is decreased) an increase in the amount that the company has in cash (the cash position is increased)
An account can be assigning to one or more ledgers. A ledger is a group of accounts for a certain purpose. If there is need for multiple ledgers because of multiple purpose, an account can perfectly well assigned to multiple ledgers. When Ledgers are in real physical books, this is not possible. When ledgers are digital, accounts can be grouped into multiple groups at the same time. This practice is very rarely taught into courses for accounting, but in digital accounting, it is common practice.
Examples: stock account of a shop, cash register, bank account, financial accounting account, customer account, supplier account, ... Bank Account BE12 1234 5678 9012: is an individual banking account Accounts Payable, is a collective account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to its suppliers. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to suppliers. This account is managed usually in a General Ledger Supplier Account X, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to an individual supplier. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to an individual supplier. This account is managed usually in a sub-ledger. Stock Account x, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts in stock of a specific good. A payment service to take fund out of an account.
A characteristic of account which refers to the LifecycleStatus of account like opened, closed, blocked, etc.
The identifier of account like Account Number.
A characteristic of account which refers to LifecycleDate of account (e.g., ClosingDate, OpeningDate, LiveDate, etc.)
Specifies the category of account like payment account, loan account, cash account, securities account, etc.

The state of the obligations managed on the account, the result of all entries on the account.
Numerical representation of the net increases and decreases in an account at a specific point in time. (ISO20022)
Banking: Amount available in an account for withdrawal or use. Read more: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/balance.html
Bookkeeping: Difference between the debit and credit sides of an account. Read more: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/balance.html
A detailed explanation or commentary of account.

Authorisation of a card payment instruction or transaction.
Once the card and the cardholder have been successfully authenticated, authorisation is usually requested. However, this stage may be skipped in some cases (e.g. for transactions below a certain value), at the risk of the card acceptor. The terminal forwards the request for authorisation to the acquirer, to the acquirers processor or to the card scheme. If the acquirer and the issuer are one and the same, such transactions are referred to as on-us transactions and the acquiring bank carries out the authorisation itself. For transactions other than on-us transactions (i.e. where the issuer and the acquirer are not the same), authorisation may be obtained offline or online. In offline authorisations, the request is handled directly by the card acceptors terminal. In most cases, however, the authorisation is online and the request passes from the terminal to the acquirer. The acquirer may directly authorise or refuse the transaction, but will in most cases pass the transaction to a switching centre. The switching centre transfers the authorisation request and transaction information to the appropriate issuer or the authorisation platform (which may be the card scheme or a third-party service provider). The authorisation process usually includes checking the card details against a list of cards that have been reported as having been lost, stolen, used fraudulently or counterfeited. Checks on balances and card limits (i.e. daily and monthly limits) are usually also carried out. (Payment System ECB)
Outcome of the transaction at the acceptor. (ISO20022)
Indicate that the acceptor has forced the transaction in spite of the authorisation result (online or offline), or incident to complete the transaction. (ISO20022)
Transaction authorisation deadline to complete the related payment. (ISO20022)
Response to an authorisation request. (ISO20022)
Value assigned by the authorising party. (ISO20022)
Result of the cardholder verification address checks on the street number and the postal code. (ISO20022)
Result of the printed CSC (Card Security Code) validation. (ISO20022)
Result of an e-commerce authentication process. (ISO20022)
Incident occurring during the transaction. (ISO20022)
A person to whom a payment card is issued and who is authorised to use that card. (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from ECB)

A financial institution that makes payment cards available to cardholders, authorises transactions at point-of-sale (POS) terminals or automated teller machines (ATMs) and guarantees payment to the acquirer for transactions that are in conformity with the rules of the relevant scheme. (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from ECB)
Entity accepting payment related cards. (ISO20022)
Entity acquiring card payment transactions. (ISO20022)
Party performing the card payment transaction. (ISO20022)

Network for handling the card-based transaction (e.g. Visa, MC, AMEX, Diners, etc.)
A card network are networks of issuing and acquiring banks through which payment cards of some certain brand are processed. two types of card networks can be pointed out, namely, credit card associations (Visa, MasterCard, Discover, Amex, etc.) and PINless debit card networks (NYCE, PULSE, Maestro, Interlink, Cirrus, etc.).
Card networks are financial services companies that enables, processes and settles payments between card issuing banks and merchant banks worldwide. Examples are Visa, MasterCard, Discover, RuPay etc.
A card network is a system of connecting merchants and card issuers. A middle person that collects funds from card issuer and pays it to the merchant. Visa and MasterCard are examples of card networks.
A clearing process for card based transactions.

A formal or informal common understanding between two or more (legal competent) parties concerning one or more subject matters expressed in a set of arrangements, terms and conditions. (adapted from Legal System and FIBO)
Date on which the agreement was signed by all parties. (ISO20022)

Specifies the category of agreement. Agreement type is very often referred to product. But, the term product does not cover all kinds of agreements. An Agreement can be subtyped from the perspective of various aspects of interest. One can classify the agreement from the perspective of format type (e.g., verbal agreement, written agreement). Other one can classify agreement based on duration like short-term agreement or long-term agreement.
Period during which the agreement is valid
LifecycleStatus of agreement (e.g., potential, offered, confirmed, completed, signed, terminated)
The identifier of agreement like Agreement Number, Contract Number, Contract Registration Number, etc.

A characteristic of agreement which refers to 1) LifecycleDate of agreement (e.g., SignedDate, TerminatedDate, FulfilledDate) OR 2) ArrangedDate of agreement (e.g., StartingDate, EndingDate, ValidityPeriod, EffectiveDate).

Authentication of card payment instruction or transaction.
Once the transaction has been initiated, the card and cardholder need to be authenticated. Authentication of the card usually involves reading the magnetic strip or chip, or checking the CVC/CVV2 (a three-digit code printed without relief on the back of the card, data which is not included in the magnetic strip) for card-not-present transactions. The cardholders identity is usually authenticated using a PIN code or a signature. (Payment System ECB)
Cardholder for which an authentication is provided (ISO20022)
Method used to authenticate a person. (ISO20022)
Entity or object in charge of verifying the person authenticity. (ISO20022)
Value used to authenticate the owner of the payment card. (ISO20022)
Encrypted personal identification number (PIN) format.
Personal Identification Number (PIN) for authentication. (ISO20022)
Specifies the result of the authentication. e.g. Denial, NonParticipation, UnableToAuthenticate, WithCryptogram, WithoutCryptogram, ...
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.
An arrangement into which both parties confirm on an interest product feature.
Specifies the type of interest associated with a trade. (ISO20022)

An arranged InterestRate
InterestRate: A price generally expressed as a percentage for the use of capital unit for a certain period
Specifies the type of rate used to calculate the interest. (ISO20022)
Period during which the interest rate has to be applied.
An arranged InterestRatePlan
A service offered as a feature of a product.
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.

An arrangement to do or not to do something with an account.
An arrangement that has an account as the subject matter.
An arrangement which specifies to charge fees when banking transactions did take place, accompanied by the modalities to calculate and charge the fees and the related terms and conditions.
Specifies the type of fee which is applicable to the amount of goods/services. (ISO20022)
Base amount that would be applied when the service is requested.
Rate used to calculate the amount of the adjustment, allowance, charge or fee. (ISO20022)
Period during which the fee is applicable. (ISO20022)
Date on which the fee needs to be paid. - It is not nessessary a date and could be expressed as a calander or formula or events that would be fulfiled.
An arranged FeeRatePlan
Method used to authenticate a cardholder.
Arrangement on the provision and use of product instruments.
The actions that can be taken by using the device(type) to which the arrangement refers to.
The fee due for the reception and/or use of the device(type) to which the arrangement refers to.
A dispute related to the card payment.
A settlement process for card-based transaction (transactions between the Issuers and the Acquirers through the Card Networks).

A transaction processing software (system) which receives transaction request from more than one interface ( ATM, POS , mPOS, payment gateway and etc) and obtain authroisation for transaction from debit cards or credit card hosts or prepaid card host.
Set of integrated applications that provides centralised services such as clearing, netting, reconciliation, trading and/or settlement. (ISO20022)
The time schedule that system services are available for use.

Entry means Posting to an account that results in an increase or decrease to a balance. (ISO20022)
An entry posted/booked in the account.

The amount of funds entered on the account
has a plus or minus sign
The currency in which the AccountEntryAmount is expressed
Posting events to the log.
A device allowing the use of payment cards at a physical (not virtual) point of sale. The payment information is captured either manually on paper vouchers or by electronic means.
A PaymentInstruction initiated by PaymentCard
Instruction to pay an amount of money to an ultimate beneficiary, on behalf of an originator. (ISO20022)
A classification of an instance of a payment instruction as an inbound or outbound payment.

Classification of a payment instruction according to the arrangement type that made it possible/generated it
There are several ways a payment instruction can be created - as a consequence of the fulfillment of an arrangement ("a "xxx-FulfillmentEvent" (a standing order instruction is also the fulfillment of an arrangement) - as an instruction given by a customer (made possible by a payment service arrangement), e.g. a credit transfer, a card payment, a withdrawal, a deposit, a direct debit instruction.
The payment system requested to be used in a payment instruction.
Type of critical dates of a payment transaction executed by the payment order like RequestedExecutionDate.
